title: The Entropic Brain Hypothesis of How Psychedelics Work EXPLAINED | Dr. Robin Carhart-Harris's Theory

media:group.media:title: The Entropic Brain Hypothesis of How Psychedelics Work EXPLAINED | Dr. Robin Carhart-Harris's Theory
media:group.media:description:
In this video, I go over The Entropic Brain Hypothesis of how psychedelic drugs affect the brain and mind. 

This theory was originally proposed by leading psychedelic neuroscientist Dr. Robin Carhart-Harris in his 2014 paper, available at: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnhum.2014.00020/full

As always, I do my best to present the ideas in a way that anyone can understand, whether they have a scientific background or not!

This video is also preparation for my deep dive into Dr. Carhart-Harris's more recent theory, which integrates these ideas into a larger framework. This framework is called the RElaxed Beliefs under pSychedelics (REBUS) model. Look for a video on that in the near future!

More info about me:

Manesh Girn is a Neuroscience PhD student at McGill University and has been lead or co-author on over a dozen scientific publications and book chapters on topics including psychedelics, meditation, daydreaming, and brain networks. 

Manesh currently has ongoing collaborations with Robin Carhart-Harris and others at the Imperial College Center for Psychedelic Research and is investigating the brain changes underlying psilocybin, LSD, and DMT.
